review_id:
Tourist trap and a massive waste of time.

I remember visiting the more authentic parts of the park before all the development but they have tried to turn it into a theme park, with the queues, and the shiny front, but minus the fun.

Not to say that I expected the fun, I would have appreciated the cultural aspects of the park if the management didn't charge so much for the experience.

Why was this a tourist trap?

At the first entrance, we were told that our entry tickets included a buggy ride from quite an unfriendly driver (can't fault him, it was a thankless job of driving visitors up and down a hill the entire day) to the foot of the massive statue. The statue was impressive, but when we went into the building, and walked all the way to the end of a hallway, we were the told that there was another additional charge for visiting the interior of the Garuda Wisnu building.

If not, that was it. We could either walk down or take the buggy back down to the midpoint where we could walk around to visit the other monuments. This is about the most authentic part of the experience and well worth the visit, but not the entire facade.

The tickets also included entry to some cultural shows, and a museum. All of these felt artificial somehow.

Is it a problem with the ticket value? I don't think so, I think it is just a problem with not setting expectations from the start, thus making visitors feel cheated.

review_translated_text:
One of the places you must visit when you go to Bali. Garuda Wisnu Kencana Park offers a garden with a unique atmosphere and statues which are the main focus of this place. There are 3 large statues in this place, the Vishnu statue, the Garuda statue, and the largest is the Garuda Wisnu Kencana statue. Apart from the three statues, there are also several statues scattered along the entrance to the back of this place.

This place not only offers iconic statues, there is also a place to buy various souvenirs, there is a performance stage, Asana Photo Studio, and a restaurant.

To get to the ticket purchase area from the parking lot, a free shuttle bus is provided. Arriving at the place of purchase of tickets, you can buy cash or non-cash. Domestic ticket price Rp. 125,000 per person, but usually there are promotions. There are two routes you can choose to enter, walking for free or taking a shuttle but paying Rp. 30,000 per person. My suggestion is to just walk to enjoy the atmosphere around the entrance.

I also suggest going to the Asana Photo Studio and taking a photo package with Traditional Balinese/Javanese Clothes with dozens of interesting backgrounds.

Don't forget to watch Balinese dance performances in the theater every hour from 10:00 WITA until afternoon, and the final dance at sunset is the iconic Kecak dance.

There is also a restaurant but I didn't have time to go in, you can exchange your entrance ticket for free water.

During the day this place is quite hot, don't forget to bring an umbrella and it's best to come in the afternoon at 15:00

review_id:
This place is a must visit when you're in Ubud. It was the highlight of the trip.

Purchasing tickets was super easy and fast for us. There were plenty of people there but it's a big place so it didn't feel too crowded.

The monkeys are amazing to look at. The human expressions and how they use their hands makes it so easy to see how they're our distant cousins.

There were plenty of staff around to assist in most places and there was a fun addition 'monkey selfie' you can pay 50k for which is worth it for great pics and getting even closer to a monkey.

When they yawn or bare their teeth you can see their huge sharp teeth which is a reminder to show them respect.

So long as you follow the very clearly marked rules you should be fine, but be prepared for some monkeys to try and get close or even on you. It's fine as long as you stand up and encourage them to get off quickly.

We were there for a good few hours and it was such a wonderful experience. We saw two people get bit by the monkeys but they were not following the rules and were getting a bit too close to them.

Even just the grounds are a wonderful thing to see. So beautifully kept and adorned with many old looking statues and shrines.

Would recommend to everyone to do this when in Ubud!

review_id:
The Sacred Monkey Forest in Bali is nothing short of a thrilling jungle adventure that immerses you in a realm where nature, spirituality, and mischievous monkeys converge. From the moment you step into this enchanting sanctuary, you are greeted by the lively chatter of long-tailed macaques and the lush, vibrant foliage that forms the backdrop to this captivating experience.

Walking through the ancient moss-covered stone entrance feels like stepping into a mystical realm where centuries-old temples stand in harmony with the playful antics of the resident monkeys. The air is filled with an electric energy, a palpable fusion of the sacred and the wild.

The monkeys, considered sacred guardians of the forest, are the true stars of this show. Their cheeky antics, acrobatic displays, and curious nature create an atmosphere of constant excitement. From adorable infants clinging to their mothers to mischievous adolescents engaging in playful games, every corner of the forest is alive with the dynamic energy of these captivating creatures.

Interacting with the monkeys adds an element of unpredictability to the experience. Whether they're gently accepting a banana from your hand or demonstrating their agility by leaping from branch to branch, each encounter is a unique and exhilarating moment. It's a delightful dance of coexistence between humans and primates, set against the backdrop of ancient mossy temples and towering banyan trees.

The forest itself is a work of art, a carefully preserved ecosystem that invites exploration. The pathways wind through dense foliage, revealing hidden shrines, moss-covered statues, and tranquil streams. The ambient sounds of rustling leaves and distant monkey calls create a symphony that accompanies your journey through this natural wonderland.

The sacred temples within the forest add a layer of cultural richness to the experience. The intricate stone carvings and ancient architecture transport you back in time, offering a glimpse into Bali's spiritual heritage. The juxtaposition of the sacred and the untamed creates a harmonious balance that is both awe-inspiring and invigorating.

In conclusion, the Sacred Monkey Forest in Bali is not just a tourist attraction; it's a thrilling escapade into a world where nature and spirituality intertwine. The mischievous monkeys, ancient temples, and lush greenery combine to create an experience that is as exhilarating as it is enchanting. If you're seeking adventure, cultural immersion, and a touch of wildlife magic, the Sacred Monkey Forest is a must-visit destination that promises a journey like no other.

Desa Panglipuran di Bali adalah sebuah destinasi yang benar-benar memikat dengan kekayaan budaya dan keindahan alamnya. Desa ini dikenal dengan gelar desa terbersih di dunia, dan itu tidak mengherankan. Desa Panglipuran memancarkan keindahan yang luar biasa, dengan jalan-jalan yang bersih dan rapi, serta rumah-rumah tradisional Bali yang khas.

Salah satu hal yang paling mencolok adalah kekompakan masyarakat setempat dalam menjaga tradisi dan budaya mereka. Mereka dengan tekun memelihara adat-istiadat Bali, yang tercermin dalam arsitektur desa, pakaian, dan festival budaya yang diadakan secara berkala. Ini memberikan pengunjung pengalaman yang otentik dalam menjelajahi kehidupan sehari-hari orang Bali.

Selain budayanya yang kaya, Desa Panglipuran juga menawarkan pemandangan alam yang memukau. Dikelilingi oleh sawah hijau yang menghijau dan pemandangan gunung, desa ini adalah tempat yang sempurna untuk bersantai sambil menikmati keindahan Bali.

Panglipuran Village in Bali is a truly enchanting destination with its rich culture and natural beauty. This village is known as the cleanest village in the world, and that is not surprising. Panglipuran Village exudes extraordinary beauty, with clean and tidy streets, and typical traditional Balinese houses.

One of the most striking things is the solidarity of the local community in maintaining their traditions and culture. They diligently maintain Balinese customs, which are reflected in the village architecture, clothing, and cultural festivals held periodically. This gives visitors an authentic experience in exploring the daily life of Balinese people.

Apart from its rich culture, Panglipuran Village also offers stunning natural views. Surrounded by verdant green rice fields and mountain views, this village is the perfect place to relax while enjoying the beauty of Bali.

With its title as the cleanest village in the world, Panglipuran Village not only shows its commitment to the environment but also shows the world how keeping the environment clean is an important part of local culture and identity. This is a wonderful example of how culture and environment can come together in an extraordinary village.

Don't forget your camera, because you'll want to take lots of pictures. You might even see farmers working in the fields. If you like nature, this is a place you shouldn't miss. It's not just pretty to look at, it also makes you feel really relaxed.

review_id:
When I first came here in October 2019, I was in or of the gardens and statues and couldn't wait to bring my friends here. Sadly now September 2023 it is a lot different. The entry price has significantly increased and presentation standard has dropped significantly. I understand that with the closure during COVID the gardens wouldn't have been attended to like they were previously and they need to bounce back but to be charged more for entry with a lower presentation doesn't sit well compared to other gardens we saw during our holiday. Furthermore there was a wedding reception in progress the day we attended, which we weren't informed about. Whilst we weren't told that we couldn't enter those sections of the grounds, we chose not to, as the reception was still in progress and in respect to the bride and groom. Some of the guests were walking around the gardens and wanted to take photos with us, which we participated with and had some fun with them. If we had of been made aware there was a wedding reception in progress, we would have come back a different day so we could have seen all the grounds.
With that said, it is a nice place and hopefully over time the gardens will get back to their former glory.
Previously I rated the grounds 5 out of 5, unfortunately this time it is 3 out of 5. Good luck team and hopefully the gardens return to the former glory.

Tukad Cepung waterfall is located in Bangli, 1.5 hours from Denpasar Bali.
After arriving at the vehicle parking lot, you can walk directly to the entrance (see signage) to buy an entrance ticket.
The entrance ticket is 20,000 / pax for domestic tourists and foreign tourists.
After buying the ticket, you can immediately walk nursing the downhill road and stairs for about 20 minutes.
Many of the steps are high, but handrails are provided to make it easier for visitors to go down and up.
Arriving at the bottom of the ravine, take the left direction, along the water flow with a few rocks.
It's best to use comfortable footwear for walking; you'll enter ankle-deep water.
After arriving at the main waterfall, you can take photos following the queue of other visitors.

Tiket masuk 20.000/ pax untuk turis domestik dan turis asing.
Setelah membeli tiket, bisa langsung berjalan menyusui jalan dan tangga yang menurun sekitar 20 menit.
Banyak anak tangga yang tinggi, tapi diberi pegangan tangan sehingga memudahkan pengunjung untuk turun maupun naik.
Setiba di dasar jurang, ambil arah ke kiri, menyusuri aliran air dengan sedikit  bebatuan.
Sebaiknya menggunakan alas kaki yang nyaman untuk berjalan; akan masuk ke dalam air setinggi mata kaki.
Setelah tiba di air terjun utama, bisa ambil foto mengikuti antrian pengunjung lainnya.
review_translated_text:
Tukad Cepung waterfall is located in Bangli, 1.5 hours from Denpasar Bali.
After arriving at the vehicle parking lot, you can walk directly to the entrance (see signage) to buy an entrance ticket.
The entrance ticket is 20,000 / pax for domestic tourists and foreign tourists.
After purchasing the ticket, you can immediately walk nursing the downhill road and stairs for about 20 minutes.
Many of the steps are high, but handrails are provided to make it easier for visitors to go down and up.
Arriving at the bottom of the ravine, take the left direction, along the water flow with a few rocks.
It's best to use comfortable footwear for walking; you'll enter ankle-deep water.
After arriving at the main waterfall, you can take photos following the queue of other visitors.

The walk is not difficult, but not suitable for kids and elderly because you'll have to climb on rocks, wade through some water. I had fun going on this walk. The water can be a little deep in some areas, if your height is less than 1.6metres then you probably can't reach the bottom. Best to wear covered footwear because if you are wading through the water, you'll definitely hit some rocks and the rocks can be very slippery.

review_id:
WOW! What an amazing experience. Had absolutely no idea how this activity would play out. Arrived with some idea of watching a river flow through the canyon, but had a huge shock when it actually started. Only swim wear is needed, no shoes, no hats. Make sure to bring a changes of clothing. Guides are capable to keep a phone in a waterproof bag for some great photos.

Walking down to the canyon barefoot, I did start to doubt if I would be able to do this, but the super awesome guides quickly made the group feel at ease and "empowered". We walked criss-cross in the river, thought the canyon, some places climbing the rocks, with the help of the guides. Strong current and rocks did not make this hour long experience any easier, but it was amazing to come out the other side and being able to sit under a beautiful waterfall. Then taking a walk back to the start through the amazing rice plantations to a included lunch or beer option. Clean showers and lockers available form the get go, also two hours experience to a second waterfall if you are still up to it.

This is not for the faint at heart, but easy enough to have a fun day out. Can highly recommend. The very capable, experienced and entertaining guides made up a good part of this experience.

review_id:
The canyon entrance is easy to find, right next to a road, and the entrance ticket also includes a private guide, water & a meal.

There will be lockers to leave your bagpacks there, and the guide will carry a waterproof bag so you can put your phone/sunglasses/etc there that you want to use during-after the tour.

The tour itself is very enjoyable, the views are amazing, you have the option to climb like a boulderer on the rock walls, but you can always choose to swim instead if you feel unsafe - the guide will show the way and help you whenever needed. He will also make photos of you if you'd like.

I highly recommend coming in flipflops as you will need to climb barefoot, and the slippers fit easily into the guide's bag.
Also, prepare to get fully wet as the water is quite deep in some places, so come in swimsuit.

At the end of the trip there is a short walk among the rice fields, so prepare with a t-shirt or sunscreen. Also, right at the end of the canyon there is a small shop where you can buy beer / water / extremely fresh coconut to freshen up a bit.

After getting back to the starting point you can have your selected meal (+ this is a restaurant so you can order extra/drink). You can have a shower here, they also give you towels.

I highly recommend this tour as it is a beautiful scenery and unique experience!

If you know just a little about these wonderful creatures, you'd know better than coming here and pay to extend their suffering in this prison. The dolphins misadvantage is, that their face mimic always looks like they're happily smiling.... the complete opposite is the case here. I better donate my money to free them from this place and be much happier seeing them roaming free in the ocean. Please think twice before visiting this place.

review_id:
I found this recommendation on Google reviews and I wasn't disappointed!

Make sure you wear decent walking shows (flip flops are not good enough) as you will be walking for a long time (about 2-3 hours) and traversing paths along paddy fields that are uneven.

You should also make sure you put on plenty of sunscreen and wear a hat and sun shades as there are a lot of parts where you are exposed fully to the sun.

Now onto the nitty gritty. We were welcomed by Sumadi at Murni's Warung (this is where the tour starts, not at the Bali Bird Walk office), who runs the tours. She is incredibly passionate about the wildlife in the area and provided us with binoculars and a list of birds we might see on the walk.

We popped into a taxi for a 10 minute drive to the start of the tour, and then, straight away, we were bird spotting.

As well as spotting birds, we were introduced to a variety of plants and their uses, such as the Star of Bethlehem and the silver fern (very cool temporary tattoo was  demonstrated!)

I also got to see water monitor lizard, golden orb spider and gliding lizard.

And amongst all of this, we were taught about the life of a rice farmer, and how the crops are grown and which animals are good for the crops, and which ones aren't (depending on the maturity of the crops). The irrigation system was fascinating.... and the hidden rules behind how it is used... not something I thought I would find interesting!

Best spot of the day was the Java Kingfisher.

And then, we fi ish up back at Murnis Warung for lunch and a chat

Brilliant morning finding out more about the nature of Bali and how people live from someone (Sumadi) who had a wealth of information and has had a range of life experiences within the country.

review_id:
This was a wonderful experience. We jumped in without any information, and I'd like to make sure the next person knows what this is. :)

First, best way to communicate is by using WhatsApp and messaging your intent to join the bird walk. Check the website for days/hours that the walk starts. (As of right now it's Mon/Tue at 9am)
Second, the meeting point is at the golden bridge in Ubud, not at the office (the address listed is the office location.) However, we were at the office at meeting time, and they were so kind to drive over and pick us up. The drive from pickup to start of the walk is not very long- 5 minutes perhaps. Su provides guests with binoculars- so you won't miss a thing!
You will need to have local currency to pay, it was about 530,000 a person.
The group was very small, only 4, and it was absolutely the best way to learn about the culture, flora and fauna! Su (the guide) is very enthusiastic! We saw (and she identified) everything from caterpillars, spiders, and lizards to plants and birds. She took her time explaining to us the rice fields, the different stages, how they process etc and we saw rice fields in each stage (much more educational than the plantation/tourist approach you get elsewhere.)
The walking tour lasts about 3 hours- make sure you have drinking water, bug spray, and your camera(or fully charged phone!) After the walking tour the group heads to a local restaurant (lunch is included in the price.) Su continues to educate through the entire day, she is very easy to understand, has a conservation outlook, and is very knowledgeable!

The location isn't too big, which makes walking the entirety of it very manageable even in the heat. It's a decent mix of touristy yet still retains its natural beauty, meaning you can enjoy some fun amenities suck as the swings or zip lines while still seeing the step fields. I'd definitely recommend walking the entire site as it won't take long, and you'll get to enjoy all the viewpoints on offer. Well worth the visit!

The terraces themselves are stunning, with a short (2-3km) hike up and down. I'd recommend wearing secure shoes as some of the trails can be slippy, but we survived in flip flops. Worth going early in the morning or late afternoon to avoid crowds and the heat!

The accessibility of Tegenungan Waterfall adds to its appeal, as it doesn't require an arduous trek to reach. This makes it suitable for a wide range of visitors, from nature enthusiasts to families looking for a picturesque spot to unwind.

While its popularity has grown, especially in recent years, the site manages to maintain its natural charm. However, it's advisable to visit early in the day to avoid crowds and fully appreciate the serenity of the surroundings.

In conclusion, Tegenungan Waterfall is a must-visit destination in Bali, offering a harmonious blend of nature's beauty and tranquility, making it an ideal spot for those seeking a peaceful escape in the heart of this Indonesian paradise.

review_id:
A beautiful monument in tribute to a beautiful people.
During my recent visit to Denpasar, I had the privilege to visit the Bajra Sandhi Monument, an iconic landmark that stands as a silent witness to the rich history and cultural tapestry of Indonesia.

As I approached the monument, I was struck by its grandeur and architectural brilliance. The monument, with its towering structure and intricate Balinese design, serves as a proud reminder of Bali's struggle for independence. Its imposing edifice commands respect and reflects the resilience and spirit of the Balinese people.

The monument is nestled amidst a lush and well-maintained garden, offering a serene and peaceful environment to ponder upon the historical narratives that it embodies. Inside, the museum offers an enlightening journey through various phases of Balinese history, depicted through a series of dioramas that are both detailed and captivating. The galleries are well-curated, providing a seamless blend of education and visual appeal.

Visitors also have the opportunity to ascend to the top of the monument, where they are greeted with a panoramic view of Denpasar. This vantage point offers a picturesque glimpse of the city's evolving skyline, set against the backdrop of the majestic Mount Agung. It is a sight that captures the harmonious blend of the old and the new, a testimony to Bali's continuous growth and development.

But what truly sets Bajra Sandhi Monument apart is its role as a space of reflection, where one can pause and appreciate the sacrifices made by those who fought for Bali's freedom. It is a place that evokes a deep sense of pride and reverence, making it a must-visit for anyone keen on understanding the spirit of Bali.

I would highly recommend a visit to the Bajra Sandhi Monument for both locals and tourists alike. It not only offers a glimpse into Bali's rich history but also serves as a source of inspiration, a beacon of resilience, unity, and hope. A true gem in the heart of Denpasar!
Took me about 20 minutes to walk round the in square a stunning place

For those seeking a peaceful retreat into Bali's natural wonders, Banyumala Waterfall is a must-visit, offering a refreshing and enchanting experience.

Taman Festival, Padang Galak, Bali: Keajaiban yang Tersembunyi di Balik Misteri

Bali dikenal sebagai surga tropis yang menawarkan pantai-pantai indah, budaya yang kaya, dan keindahan alam yang memukau. Namun, di tengah pesonanya yang luar biasa, ada satu tempat yang memancarkan daya tarik unik berkat misteri dan hal-hal mistisnya. Itu adalah Taman Festival di Padang Galak. Dalam ulasan positif ini, kami akan menjelajahi pesona dan ketidakbiasaan yang ada di Taman Festival yang meriah dengan misteri.

Taman Festival yang pernah berkilauan sebagai proyek hiburan terbesar di Asia Tenggara kini telah menjadi tempat yang penuh misteri dan nostalgia. Ditinggalkan sejak tahun 2000, tempat ini memegang rahasia-rahasia yang memikat para pencari petualangan dan pecinta keajaiban alam.

Yang membuat Taman Festival begitu menarik adalah pengalaman mistis yang seringkali dialami oleh pengunjung yang berani menjelajahinya. Beberapa laporan melaporkan penampakan hantu dengan sosok-sosok bayangan yang melayang di kegelapan, menambah aura misteri tempat ini. Suara-suara aneh juga sering didengar, mulai dari langkah kaki hingga bisikan yang sulit dipahami. Sensasi kehadiran tak terlihat dan pengalaman gaib yang intens juga membuat kunjungan ke Taman Festival terasa sangat unik.

Namun, apa yang perlu diingat adalah bahwa misteri-misteri ini belum dapat dipastikan. Banyak faktor seperti suasana yang terbengkalai, kondisi bangunan yang usang, dan sugesti psikologis dapat mempengaruhi pengalaman pengunjung.

Tetapi, jika Anda adalah pencinta petualangan atau penggemar hal-hal mistis, Taman Festival adalah tempat yang menarik untuk dijelajahi. Kepedulian terhadap budaya setempat dan lingkungan adalah hal yang penting saat Anda berkunjung ke tempat ini. Dengan cara ini, Anda dapat mengeksplorasi sisi misterius Bali sambil menghormati keindahan dan warisan budayanya.

Festival Park, Padang Galak, Bali: The Miracle Hidden Behind the Mystery

Bali is known as a tropical paradise that offers beautiful beaches, rich culture and stunning natural beauty. However, amidst its extraordinary charm, there is one place that exudes a unique charm thanks to its mystery and mystical things. It is the Festival Park in Padang Galak. In this positive review, we will explore the charm and unusualness that is the Festival Park that is alive with mystery.

Festival Park, which once glittered as Southeast Asia's largest entertainment project, has now become a place full of mystery and nostalgia. Abandoned since 2000, this place holds secrets that enchant adventure seekers and lovers of natural wonders.

What makes Festival Park so interesting is the mystical experience often experienced by visitors who dare to explore it. Some reports report ghostly sightings with shadowy figures floating in the darkness, adding to the aura of mystery of this place. Strange sounds are also often heard, ranging from footsteps to whispers that are difficult to understand. The sensation of an invisible presence and an intense magical experience also makes a visit to Festival Park feel very unique.

However, what you need to remember is that these mysteries are not yet certain. Many factors such as abandoned atmosphere, outdated building conditions, and psychological suggestions can influence the visitor's experience.

However, if you are an adventure lover or a fan of the mystical, Festival Park is an interesting place to explore. Concern for local culture and the environment is important when you visit this place. This way, you can explore the mysterious side of Bali while respecting its beauty and cultural heritage.

review_id:
A good waterfalls with such a unique surroundings.

If you drive a car, there's a spacious carpark for 3-4 cars but the way to get there is a bit challenging for some.

Around the carpark, there's cafe and some warungs. From there, you just need to walk about 5 mins to get to the stairs and climb down. But be really careful because the stairs are quite steep. Especially when they're wet.

There are some rocks carved around the falls.

To get to the waterfalls, you need to cross the river. Please pick a good day to come here because if it was raining a day after then the stream could be hard to cross.

Crossing can be difficult for some, but there's a guide rope which you can hang your life to it. How ever, just pray before you cross so you don't meet an anaconda swimming around or a lost crocodile.

Other than that, have fun!

review_id:
I only give two stars because the manager of this place is nice and he listened to my feedback. Also they are really trying to make a nice path and clean it, plant trees etc. going to the waterfall. It is also a community place so maybe one day this will become a really nice place (many of the negative things I say below have nothing to do with the place but generally cleanliness of water, waste management etc.). There is also a very nice Cafe where you can jump in the pool shower and have nice food and hang out in a hammock after so that's good.

Finally if you want to go and have sun under the waterfall you probably need to go in the morning as afternoon it's dark there.

The waterfall is nice but the water is murky and brown, although I suspect that this is always the case in Bali or even Indonesia so it just has to be expected I guess and the people here can definitely do nothing about it. The place is an ancient quarry (very bad for the environment) and the waterfall arose from that. But at least they are trying to valorize that with local artists carving into the stone so I guess they are trying their best.

The one thing however is that I am always happy to pay to contribute to community work (20K), but I am not Ok that then plastic is everywhere along the river. I know it's not easy to clean up but I provided that as main feedback that they should clean more and also put signs everywhere that people should collect their rubbish and respect nature.

Finally the waterfall could be clean but I don't really trust the cleanliness of rivers here (due also to bad experiences) and you have to go through the river to get to the waterfall. So I didn't.

To get to the waterfall from the parking lot, you have to walk some steps, but both sides are still beautiful and fresh, the walls on both sides of the stairs are also filled with carvings that add a magical and beautiful feel to the place.
The entrance fee is IDR 20,000
Be careful as the stairs are quite slippery.

review_translated_text: a belong hill is a hill located in a village where not many vehicles pass outside the area. There is someone who collects illegal fees, a little disappointed even though this hill has no fees from the relevant agencies. The parking lot is paved uphill, access to the top is through a steep path, there is a slight landslide on the path leading up. Only a stretch of reeds and a few rubber trees on this hill, there is no definite spot here so you can freely determine the location of the photo here. Come in the morning so it's not crowded with other visitors, because this place has a plus for calm while looking at the beautiful Klungkung district and from a distance you can also see Lembongan Island which is included in Klungkung regency.

review_id:
Mixed feelings about this review because I absolutely love the place but don't want it to change from too many visitors!
My favourite waterfall I've visited in Bali, probably because me and my friend were the only visitors there. The manager? Kind of guy or care taker is great and got us fresh coconuts, he has a donation box for people to give what they feel is worth and I have way more than the other waterfalls ask just because the way he has looked after the land and maintained it with planting trees and local medicinal herbs.

He got us to ride all the way down to it instead of parking up the top but it's a steep difficult ride on a scooter if you aren't experienced (my friend fell off) otherwise it's a few hundred metre walk and then further steps down.

Great place to visit

review_translated_text:
Capture the waterfall between Kintamani Ubub.
When you enter you can access it by motorbike up to the waterfall gate, if you use a car you have to stop in a residential area, and walk up to the waterfall via a footpath, the natural atmosphere is really good, lots of beautiful tall trees, after passing through the waterfall gate we going down the artificial stairs, not steep, very easy and not slippery either. From here we can hear the sound of the waterfall, when we arrive at the waterfall we can bathe there because the water is clean and cold too.
Enjoy.
Oh yes, the entry fee is still voluntary because it is managed by local residents.

There is a lovely trail along the stream coming down from the waterfall. The waterfall is a bit tucked away but definitely worth the journey to get there!
